lgcpspatial.plot module

plot.py: A subset of plotting helpers copied from neurotools/graphics/plot, and some new helper routines to reduce notebook clutter

lgcpspatial.plot.simpleaxis(ax=None)[source]

Only draw the bottom and left axis lines

Parameters

ax (optional, defaults to plt.gca() if None) –

lgcpspatial.plot.pixels_to_xfigureunits(n, ax=None, fig=None)[source]

Converts a measurement in pixels to units of the current figure width scale

lgcpspatial.plot.pixels_to_yfigureunits(n, ax=None, fig=None)[source]

Converts a measurement in pixels to units of the current figure height scale

lgcpspatial.plot.nudge_axis_left(dx, ax=None)[source]

Moves the left x-axis limit, keeping the right limit intact. This changes the width of the plot.

Parameters

  • dx (number) – Amount (in pixels) to adjust axis

  • ax (axis, default None) – If None, uses gca()

lgcpspatial.plot.nudge_axis_right(dx, ax=None)[source]

Moves the right x-axis limit, keeping the left limit intact. This changes the width of the plot.

Parameters

  • dx (number) – Amount (in pixels) to adjust axis

  • ax (axis, default None) – If None, uses gca()

lgcpspatial.plot.nudge_axis_x(dx, ax=None)[source]

This does not change the width of the axis

Parameters

  • dx (number) – Amount (in pixels) to adjust axis

  • ax (axis, default None) – If None, uses gca()

lgcpspatial.plot.nudge_axis_y_pixels(dy, ax=None)[source]

moves axis dy pixels. Direction of dy may depend on axis orientation. Does not change axis height.

lgcpspatial.plot.adjust_axis_height_pixels(dy, ax=None)[source]

resize axis by dy pixels. Direction of dy may depends on axis orientation. Does not change the baseline position of axis.

lgcpspatial.plot.get_ax_size(ax=None, fig=None)[source]

Gets tha axis size in figure-relative units

lgcpspatial.plot.hcolorbar(vmin=None, vmax=None, cmap=None, title='', ax=None, sideways=False, border=True, spacing=5, width=15, shrink=1.0, labelpad=10, fontsize=10)[source]

Matplotlib’s colorbar function is pretty bad. This is less bad. r’$mathrm{mu V}^2$’

Parameters

  • vmin (number) – min value for colormap

  • vmax (number) – mac value for colormap

  • cmap (colormap) – what colormap to use

  • title (string) – Units for colormap

  • ax (axis) – optional, defaults to plt.gca(). axis to which to add colorbar

  • sideways (bool) – Flips the axis label sideways

  • border (bool) – Draw border around colormap box?

  • spacing (number) – distance from axis in pixels. defaults to 5

  • width (number) – width of colorbar in pixels. defaults to 15

  • labelpad (number) – padding between colorbar and title in pixels, defaults to 10

  • fontsize (number) – label font size, defaults to 12

Returns

colorbar axis

Return type

axis

lgcpspatial.plot.circular_gaussian_smooth(x, sigma)[source]

Smooth signal x with gaussian of standard deviation sigma Circularly wrapped using Fourier transform

Parameters

  • sigma (standard deviation) –

  • x (1D array-like signal) –

lgcpspatial.plot.circularly_smooth_colormap(cm, s)[source]

Smooth a colormap with cirular boundary conditions

s: sigma, standard dev of gaussian smoothing kernel in samples cm: color map, array-like of RGB tuples

Parameters

  • cm (colormap) –

  • s (smoothing radius) –

Returns

RBG – Colormap smoothed with circular boundary conditions.

Return type

np.ndarray

lgcpspatial.plot.unit_crosshairs(draw_ellipse=True, draw_cross=True)[source]
lgcpspatial.plot.covellipse_from_points(q, **kwargs)[source]

Helper to construct covariance ellipse from collection of 2D points q encoded as complex numbers.

lgcpspatial.plot.covariance_crosshairs(S, p=0.95, draw_ellipse=True, draw_cross=True, mode='2D')[source]

For 2D Gaussians these are the confidence intervals p | sigma 90 : 4.605 95 : 5.991 97.5: 7.378 99 : 9.210 99.5: 10.597

  • Get the eigenvalues and vectors of covariance S

  • Prepare crosshairs for a unit standard normal

  • Transform crosshairs into covariance basis

Parameters

  • S (2D covariance matrix) –

  • p (fraction of data ellipse should enclose) –

  • draw_ellipse (whether to draw the ellipse) –

  • draw_cross (whether to draw the crosshairs) –

  • mode (2D or 1D;) – If 2D, ellipse will reflect inner p of probability mass If 1D, ellipse will represent threshold for p significance for a 1-tailed test in any direction.

Returns

path – 2×NPOINTS array of (x,y) path data for plotting

Return type

np.float32

lgcpspatial.plot.good_colorbar(vmin=None, vmax=None, cmap=None, title='', ax=None, sideways=False, border=True, spacing=5, width=15, labelpad=10, fontsize=10, vscale=1.0, va='c')[source]

Matplotlib’s colorbar function is pretty bad. This is less bad. r’$mathrm{mu V}^2$’

Parameters

  • vmin (number) – min value for colormap

  • vmax (number) – mac value for colormap

  • cmap (colormap) – what colormap to use

  • title (string) – Units for colormap

  • ax (axis) – optional, defaults to plt.gca(). axis to which to add colorbar

  • sideways (bool) – Flips the axis label sideways

  • border (bool) – Draw border around colormap box?

  • spacing (number) – distance from axis in pixels. defaults to 5

  • width (number) – width of colorbar in pixels. defaults to 15

  • labelpad (number) – padding between colorbar and title in pixels, defaults to 10

  • fontsize (number) – label font size, defaults to 12

  • vscale (float) – height adjustment relative to parent axis, defaults to 1.0

  • va (str) – vertical alignment; “bottom” (‘b’), “center” (‘c’), or “top” (‘t’)

Returns

colorbar axis

Return type

axis

lgcpspatial.plot.draw_compass(xy0=(1.1+0.65j), r=0.03, cmap_fn=<matplotlib.colors.LinearSegmentedColormap object>, delta=18)[source]

Draw a hue-wheel compass rose.

Parameters

  • xy0 (center of compass encoded as x+iy complex number) –

  • r (size of compass, defaults to 0.03) –

  • cmap_fn (circular colormap to use for compass) –

  • delta (displacement of lab) –
